citation.article-title: Pseudonocardia asaccharolytica sp. nov. and Pseudonocardia sulfidoxydans sp. nov., two new dimethyl disulfide-degrading actinomycetes and emended description of the genus Pseudonocardia.

p.s: Description of Pseudonocardia asaccharolytica sp. nov.

Pseudonocardia asaccharolytica (a.sac.cha.ro.ly'ti.ca. Gr. pref. a not; M.L. n. saccharum sugar; Gr. adj. lyticum dissolving; M.L. fem. adj. asaccharolytica referring to the failure to produce acid from carbohydrates)
Forms a yellow vegetative mycelium on TSB agar that fragments easily into rod-shaped and coccoid elements.
Aerial mycelium is white with long chains of oval spores.
Formation of swollen hyphal segments with up to 2 Î¼m diameter.
Does not decompose adenine, L-tyrosine, xanthine and hypoxanthine.
No acid production from glucose, rhamnose, xylose, fructose, trehalose, cellobiose, mannitol, sorbitol, erythritol, maltose, lactose, arabinose, adonitol and salicin.
Phosphatidylmethylethanolamine, hydroxyphosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylinositol mannoside, diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylglycerol are present.
Major fatty acids are iso-branched hexadecanoate and hexadecanoate.
Small amounts of 10-methyl fatty acids (16:0 10-methyl, 17:0 10-methyl and 18:0 10-methyl) are present.
Strains 576, 577, 578 and 580 were isolated from tree-bark compost biofilters from an animal-rendering plant.
